div1.p: Houston provides news of Mabel Lazear and the children, as well as the pension efforts.

div1.head: Letter from Martha P. Houston to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, January 11, 1902
div1.p:
Your letter has
just reached me. I was so interested
to hear about your little visit with
Nell. It is such a comfort and joy
to me to know that you can see
each other, and your letters are always
so interesting-

Dear little Houston often speaks of
Baltimore ganny. Mabel bought some
of the toasted bread. (I don't know how
to spell the German name? and he
said Baltimore ganny bought me
some like that. It was some little
time you remembered? so you see
he does not forget anything
Last night he said. When we go to
Baltimore Christine (the nurse) can't
go with us and I said who will take
care of baba on the train.
dis ganny, and Mama will
take care of Huse.

I wish you could hear him say
Houston Lazear - it is so cute,
And little Peggy running around
with her creeper on, she always
calls me “Darmiss”. and says
Gad bye to everyone-

Mabel is still occupied with
her business letters. she received
such a nice letter from
GovernorGeneral Wood of Havana- he also
inclosed a copy of one he had
written to Mr Dalzell which was
certainly a most loving tribute to Jesse,
and explaining matters in references to
Jesse's work better than any one
else could have done-

I was so sorry to know you had
not received your box. Have you
the bill of layding

The little blue nighty came yesterday, as soon as arrived
it was delivered to Houston to unwrap. he was delighted
with it, and if he were awake as I write I have no doubt
would express his thanks - Sometimes I ask him what I
shall say to Ganny, and says witte- “write me a
letter”- Mabel & I sometimes talk of the East, and think if
our lives are spared, we would wish to go sometimes
before we would be obliged to pay any fare for the
babies- I think it so strange about your box? We will
enquire at this end of the route - Thus far we are have
no rain this Winter, and the dry weather brings colds.
I have been staying in town for a few days trying to get
rid of mine. Pardon brevity this time.

Please remember me to Mrs Seth & family
With love & best wishes to your own dear self
div1.closer:
Martha P Houston. (Turn Over)
AC
L
In Jennie's Christmas letter
she said there was a lovely
article in the “Boston Transcript”
about the memorial for Jesse.
It was written by, President Eliott
of Harvard. although Jennie did
not know who had written it,
at this time she read it-
Dr Paton wrote Mabel they had
already collected twenty four hundred
dollars!
Jennie writes they had their Christmas
dinner at Walter's father, house
Mrs Kilham dressed two dolls in
dark blue - and presented them to
Jeannette & Teresa- but they
positively refused to take them
Jennie tried to put them in
a package but Jeannette would
have none of it - And Teresa
refused to carry her's. she said “I
might lose it on the way”
It must have been rather
embarasing to Jennie?
